author: By Michael D. Shear
title: Biden to Visit Maine After Lewiston Massacre
description: The deadliest mass shooting of the year will present the president with the familiar ritual of comforting grieving families. He will likely also press his case for gun control.
content: President Biden will travel to Maine on Friday to pay his respects to the 18 people killed and more than dozen wounded during a gunman’s rampage through a bar and bowling alley in Lewiston, Maine, last week, the White House announced.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gerald Narciso
title: Looking for a Slam-Dunk Place to Eat? Just Ask an N.B.A. Player.
description: The best basketball players on the planet travel regularly, embrace local cultures and have deep pockets — making them very credible reviewers of restaurants across the country.
content: Pick a city, any city, on the National Basketball Association’s 30-team circuit, and Kelly Olynyk, a forward for the Utah Jazz, has deep knowledge of the local restaurant scene.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tripp Mickle
title: Apple’s Sales Drop Slightly While Profit Is Up 11 Percent
description: Interest in new iPhones and services such as music and cloud storage powered the quarter, but other businesses, such as Mac sales, slowed significantly.
content: At a time when the tech industry’s biggest companies are rebounding from a post-pandemic dip, Apple is suffering through its most prolonged sales slump in more than a decade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Are Higher Rates Slowing the Economy? A Zoo Offers Clues.
description: Economists are surprised by how strong the economy remains with rates at a 22-year high. But there are some signs of slowing, if you know where to look.
content: Leesburg Animal Park in Northern Virginia has seen strong business at its Pumpkin Village festival this autumn. Even with rainy weekends and a jump in admission prices, families have been coming out to visit the petting zoo, ride on giant slides and zigzag through a hay-bale maze.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlos Lozada
title: ‘You Don’t Want to Be the Only One Sitting at the Table,’ Mitt Romney Says
description: It’s a wretched time to be an institutionalist in the Republican Party.
content: It’s a wretched time to be an institutionalist in the Republican Party. But it’s a vital time to read about one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Zinoman
title: Taylor Tomlinson to Host New CBS Late-Night Show after ‘Colbert’
description: The popular comedian will take over the show, which is based on “@midnight,” at a time when the job is being held only by men.
content: In a shake-up of the late-night television landscape, the stand-up comic Taylor Tomlinson, 29, will take over the time slot after “The Late Show With Stephen Colbert” on CBS. The move makes her not just the only woman in the job on a late-night show on network television now, but also the youngest by two decades.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 9 New Books We Recommend This Week
description: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
content: Every week in this space, we quote from our reviews of the books we recommend — but we rarely quote from the books themselves, largely because the reviews we link to do such a good job of that on their own, and with context to boot. But what the heck. This week our recommended books include a poetry collection, Robyn Schiff’s “Information Desk,” that offers a reminiscence of her post-college job at the Metropolitan Museum of Art while skipping merrily through sparkling ideas about art and nature and youth and life. Good quotes abound, as in this wry observation on the artistic temperament: “When someone tells me he’s inspired/I usually take/it to mean someone else/does his dishes.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: Can a Democrat Running the Biden Playbook Win in Deep-Red Kentucky?
description: Gov. Andy Beshear, the popular incumbent, is campaigning for re-election on abortion rights, the economy and infrastructure — but distancing himself from the unpopular president.
content: Gov. Andy Beshear of Kentucky is conducting one of this year’s most intriguing political experiments: What happens when an incumbent Democrat campaigns on President Biden’s record and agenda, but never mentions the party’s unpopular leader by name?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Eric Krupke, Olivia Natt, Summer Thomad, Rachelle Bonja, Liz O. Baylen, Dan Powell, Pat McCusker, Marion Lozano, Rowan Niemisto and Chris Wood
title: The Many Missed Warnings Before Maine’s Mass Shooting
description: The police were warned about the deteriorating mental health of an Army reservist months before a deadly shooting.
content: The mass shooting in Maine last week, which killed 18 people, was the country’s deadliest of the year. It may have also been one of the most avoidable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Shaffer
title: ‘What Happens Later’ Review: Meg Ryan Revisits the Meet-Cute
description: The rom-com queen directs and stars opposite David Duchovny in this two-hander about former lovers who reconnect after 25 years.
content: Few can compete with Meg Ryan’s rom-com résumé. As the star of three classics penned by Nora Ephron — “When Harry Met Sally,” “Sleepless in Seattle” and “You’ve Got Mail” — she may as well be the mascot of the genre’s late 1980s and ’90s golden era. “What Happens Later,” which she both directs and stars in, is an appropriate homecoming for a seasoned pro.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Koblin
title: Rangers-Diamondbacks World Series Ratings Are Lowest Ever
description: The five games averaged 9.1 million viewers, down from the previous low of 9.8 million in 2020.
content: The World Series wrapped up on Wednesday night with the Texas Rangers storming the field to celebrate the team’s first-ever championship.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Nehamas and Sharon LaFraniere
title: DeSantis Leans Into Vaccine Skepticism to Energize Struggling Campaign
description: The Florida governor has so far found little success in getting his criticism of the Trump administration’s Covid-19 policies to stick, but that has not stopped him from trying.
content: Gov. Ron DeSantis  had hoped that his response to the coronavirus pandemic, which helped propel him to a resounding re-election in Florida last year, would produce similar results in the Republican presidential primary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: An Alabama Newspaper Publisher and Reporter Are Arrested, Raising Alarms
description: The publisher of Atmore News in Atmore, Ala., and a reporter at the paper were charged with revealing grand jury evidence in an article published last month.
content: A newspaper publisher and reporter in Alabama were arrested last week and charged with disclosing grand jury evidence in an article, alarming press freedom advocates who raised First Amendment concerns.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles
title: The Beatles’ ‘Now and Then’: A Glimpse of Past Greatness
description: The “last” song with contributions from all four Beatles, made possible by new technology, finds its power in vulnerability and nostalgia.
content: It’s not a grand finale. It’s a wistful postscript.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Martha Schwendener
title: The Art Show Highlights Masters — and Artists Under the Radar
description: The Art Dealers Association of America fair at the Park Avenue Armory offers 78 international galleries with blue-chip booths, along with artisans rescued from the margins.
content: The world is in tumult but for the moment, the business of art marches on. Artists go to their studios, museums keep their doors open and art critics try to make sense of it all. Meanwhile, the Art Dealers Association of America (ADAA), a members-only organization known for its blue-chip brands, has assembled for its annual fair.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: ‘I’m Still Alive’: Sean Young Takes the Stage in ‘Ode to the Wasp Woman’
description: “I walk into a show and everybody’s kind of a little afraid. Then I hear, ‘Oh, but you’re so nice,’” the actress said of her Hollywood baggage.
content: Manhattan has dressing rooms dingier than the one in the basement of the Actors Temple Theater. But not many. Sean Young, curled into a folding chair atop peeling linoleum tiles with a smudged mirror behind her, claimed not to mind.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shaila Dewan, Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs and Chelsia Rose Marcius
title: The Signs Were All There. Why Did No One Stop the Maine Shooter?
description: Shortcomings in mental health treatment, weak laws and a reluctance to threaten personal liberties can derail even concerted attempts to thwart mass shootings.
content: Robert Card displayed a textbook set of warning signs: He was hearing voices. He told people that he was planning violence. And his behavior had markedly changed in the months leading up to the mass shooting he carried out last week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Calum Marsh
title: ‘Subject’ Review: A Question of Ethics
description: Filmmaking principles come under scrutiny in “Subject,” a documentary about the making of documentaries.
content: Many of the most compelling documentaries of the past several years, from Nathan Fielder’s HBO mini-series “The Rehearsal” to Kirsten Johnson’s self-reflexive feature “Cameraperson,” actively engage with the ethics of documentary filmmaking, posing difficult questions about participation, consent and the responsibility of the artist to the subjects of their art. These projects differ from “Subject,” Jennifer Tiexiera and Camilla Hall’s film about documentary ethics, in that their questions are posed by the filmmaking itself, threaded artfully into the documentary form. “Subject” just speaks the questions out loud, turning them into reductive fodder for talking heads.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Helen Williams, a Top Model in a Segregated Era, Is Dead at 87
description: She was one of the most photographed Black models of the 1950s and ’60s, seen mainly in magazines, like Ebony and Jet, aimed at the Black middle class.
content: Swan-necked and with an arched-eyebrow hauteur, Helen Williams was the aspirational face of the Black middle class in the 1950s and 60s — the most photographed, and highest paid, Black model of her era.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Law Firms Warn Universities About Antisemitism on Campus
description: Two dozen major Wall Street firms sent a letter to top law schools to crack down on discrimination and harassment amid an escalation in incidents targeting Jewish students.
content: With universities across the United States grappling with a rise in antisemitism since the start of the Israel-Hamas war, elite law firms are putting schools on notice. In a letter to some of the nation’s top law schools obtained by DealBook, about two dozen major Wall Street firms warned that what happens on campus could have corporate consequences.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Painting
description: What do you think this image is communicating?
content: What do you think this image is saying? How does it relate to or comment on society or current events? Can you relate to it personally? What is your opinion of its message?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: Bistate Battle Over Congestion Pricing Escalates With New Lawsuit
description: The mayor of Fort Lee, N.J., is suing New York to halt what he says is the harm the new tolling system will do to his city.
content: Good morning. It’s Thursday. We’ll find out about a second lawsuit from New Jersey challenging New York’s congestion-pricing plan. We’ll also look at a wristwatch that belonged to Andy Warhol, who said everyone would be famous for 15 minutes.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Nov. 2, 2023
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, Nov. 2, 2023.
content: An article on Wednesday about the dilemma Israel faces as it seeks to destroy Hamas and free hostages in Gaza misstated the day that the Israeli military said that Pvt. Ori Megidish had been rescued. They announced her rescue on Monday, not Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Lyons
title: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
description: Our TV critic recommends an lush nature documentary, an aesthetically ambitious comedy special and a distinctive Swedish dramedy.
content: ‘Planet Earth III’
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anatoly Kurmanaev and Isayen Herrera
title: Mercenaries or Volunteers? Economic Pain Pushes Colombian Veterans to Ukraine
description: Hundreds of experienced fighters have joined Kyiv’s ranks to improve their financial fortunes, reflecting the recruitment struggles faced by both sides of the conflict.
content: Manuel Barrios joined the battle against Russian forces in Ukraine because a bank threatened to repossess his home in Colombia. Luis Alejandro Herrera returned to the front to recover the savings he lost in a failed attempt to enter the United States through Mexico. Jhoan Cerón fought to provide for his toddler.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Will Heinrich
title: Juanita McNeely, Intense Artist of the Female Experience, Dies at 87
description: Her searing paintings, which could be sweet but also brutal, reflected her interest in the female body and what it could do.
content: Juanita McNeely, an uncompromising painter who used the language of Expressionism to immortalize the sweetest and most brutal moments of her own female experience, died on Oct. 18 in Manhattan. She was 87.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: Got Milk … Cartons? School Cafeterias Won’t, Thanks to a Shortage
description: A nationwide shortage of half-pint milk cartons is hitting schools in several states, leaving them brainstorming other ways to serve the drink to their students.
content: Half-pint cartons of milk, served in cafeterias and lunchrooms across the country, are ubiquitous on the lunch trays of millions of students. But in some districts, they will soon disappear.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Ito
title: Celebrating Literature That ‘Brings the World Close’
description: Words Without Borders, a magazine dedicated to literature in translation, is turning 20 at a fraught time. How to celebrate words when bombs are dropping?
content: Words Without Borders, one of the few magazines in the world dedicated to literature in translation, is turning 20 at a fraught time: Around the world, wars are raging. Writers are being jailed, dissident voices silenced and books banned.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Why the Jet Stream Is Helping Some International Flights Arrive Early
description: Flights traveling west to east over the Atlantic Ocean this week have had the wind on their side, pushing some landing times up to an hour ahead of schedule.
content: Passengers who were on British Airways’ Flight 112, from Kennedy International Airport in New York to Heathrow Airport outside London, received some good news early Thursday morning. The flight, which normally would have taken about six hours, was going to arrive 50 minutes early.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Asimov
title: What if Wine and Cider Had a Baby?
description: A growing number of producers are fermenting grapes, apples and other fruits together, or blending wine and ciders, to make fascinating beverages.
content: Wine is made by fermenting grapes or other fruit, although apple and pear wines are distinctive enough to have earned their own categories, cider and perry. But a growing number of producers are blurring the styles, blending grape wines and ciders or fermenting grapes and other fruit together, with remarkable delicious results.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: Olympic Hopefuls Needed a Home. A Retirement Community Stepped Up.
description: New Zealand’s curling team wanted to train with the “big boys” in Canada, and a group of enthusiastic seniors has provided housing, a cheering section and lots of advice.
content: Ben Smith never could have imagined spending the winter at a retirement home in Calgary, Alberta, sipping Caesar cocktails with three of his best friends — Anton Hood, Brett Sargon and Hunter Walker — while their octogenarian neighbors play bridge and tabletop shuffleboard.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane and Jessica Jaglois
title: Former Memphis Officer Pleads Guilty to Federal Charges in Tyre Nichols’s Death
description: The ex-officer pleaded guilty to two felony counts, becoming the first to admit culpability in the fatal beating of Mr. Nichols. As part of a plea deal, he is also expected to cooperate with a state murder prosecution.
content: Desmond Mills Jr., one of five former Memphis police officers charged in connection with the brutal beating and death of Tyre Nichols, pleaded guilty in federal court on Thursday to two felony charges of obstruction of justice and excessive force.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Kenny
title: ‘In the Court of the Crimson King’ Review: 50 Years of Off-Kilter Rock
description: Toby Amies’s documentary dives into the history of the British progressive rock band King Crimson and its chief disciplinarian, Robert Fripp.
content: The director Toby Amies’s documentary “In the Court of the Crimson King” is part road chronicle and part retrospective, and captures King Crimson, the adventurous British rock ensemble, at what may be the end of its existence. Robert Fripp, for years the band’s sole original member, has strongly suggested that its 2021 tour would be its last. (It hasn’t toured since.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Engaging and Aging on ‘The Golden Bachelor’
description: Two members of The New York Times’s Culture section discuss how a twist on a decades-old reality series has become must-watch television.
content: In August, Julia Jacobs visited a Mediterranean-style mansion in Agoura Hills, Calif., the backdrop of “The Golden Bachelor.” The show is a spinoff of the popular “Bachelor” reality TV franchise, with a surprising twist: Participants are at least 60 years old.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Santul Nerkar
title: Is a $500 Marathon Shoe You Can Race In Only Once Worth It?
description: A new Adidas model carried a runner to a world record. Athletes say they can feel a difference, but it comes with a high price tag and wears out quickly.
content: When Ashley Mateo went through a recent track workout, something felt different. She hit her intervals faster than usual, her heart rate was lower, and her feet felt lighter. When she ran her next marathon, she achieved a personal record.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angelo Fichera
title: The Horrifying Images Are Real. But They’re Not From the Israel-Gaza War
description: Videos and photos of the conflict are competing with misappropriated depictions of unrelated tragedies, a cycle that experts say diminishes the experiences of victims past and present.
content: In a video circulating online meant to convey the horrors of the war between Israel and Hamas, a small boy wails, his face caked in dust. Clinging to the sandwich he was eating when an airstrike razed his family’s home, he sobs for his two teenage sisters lost amid the chaos, one of whom would later be confirmed dead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicolas Rapold
title: ‘Sly’ Review: No More Mr. Tough Guy
description: This documentary from Thom Zimny tracks Sylvester Stallone’s life and career, though focuses too much on “Rocky” and “Rambo.”
content: “An actor is what he looks like,” Sylvester Stallone told The New York Times in 1976, and more than most stars, Stallone has been viewed as an action figure come to life. In “Sly,” the director Thom Zimny excavates the acts of self-creation behind a career that minted two indelible titular characters in “Rocky” and “Rambo” — whose underdog narratives proved highly influential.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Kennedy
title: ‘All Dirt Roads Taste of Salt’ Review: Mississippi Memories
description: Raven Jackson’s film offers a rich portrait of growing up in rural Mississippi and heralds a fresh, poetic talent.
content: The opening of Raven Jackson’s debut feature, “All Dirt Roads Taste of Salt,” announces the arrival of a filmmaker grounded in the lyrical beauty of her characters and the loamy grace of the place they so deeply inhabit. In this case, rural Mississippi.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mary Beth Gahan and J. David Goodman
title: With Rangers Win, an Overlooked Texas City Grabs the Spotlight
description: Arlington, which is wedged between Dallas and Fort Worth and overshadowed by both, is ready to celebrate the World Series victory of its hometown team.
content: During baseball season, the public buses in Houston flash a message as they rumble through the city: “Go Astros!!”
source.name: The New York Times

title: 10 Stellar New York Soups to Keep You Warm
description: Wonton soup, goat pepper soup, matzo balls and more soothing classics.
content: Not everybody loves soup. This is made clear to me every time I suggest ordering a bowlful and everyone at the table looks down and acts as if I hadn’t spoken. I understand some of the reluctance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Delger Erdenesanaa
title: 35 Years After Addressing Congress, James Hansen Still Has Climate Warnings
description: The former NASA scientist James Hansen says in a new paper that global temperatures will pass a major milestone this decade, faster than other estimates predict.
content: Global warming may be happening more quickly than previously thought, according to a new study by a group of researchers including former NASA scientist James Hansen, whose testimony before Congress 35 years ago helped raise broad awareness of climate change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Heather Senison
title: Homes for Sale in Manhattan and Queens
description: This week’s properties are in Yorkville, on Central Park West and in Sunnyside.
content: A two-bedroom, one-bath, roughly 850-square-foot apartment with a windowed eat-in kitchen, a windowed bathroom, an office nook, a walk-in closet and windowed air-conditioning, on the third floor of a six-story prewar building with a live-in super, bike room, video intercom, shared basement storage and shared laundry. Mihal Gartenberg, 212-327-9677, Coldwell Banker Warburg; cbwarburg.com
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Louise Rafkin
title: After the Divorce, a Different Kind of Family
description: This couple survived tragedies during their relationship, but they couldn’t overcome tight finances and a drinking problem. Today, their love “is like that of brother and sister.”
content: In Unhitched, couples tell the stories of their relationships, from romance to vows to divorce to life afterward.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Hubbard and Euan Ward
title: Hezbollah’s Leader to Speak for First Time Since Hamas Attacked Israel
description: Many in the region are watching Hassan Nasrallah’s speech for insights into whether Hezbollah will escalate its battle with Israel.
content: Hassan Nasrallah, the leader of the Lebanese militant group Hezbollah,  will break his silence on the war in Gaza on Friday in a speech that many in the region expect will provide insights into whether the group will escalate its battle with Israel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Small
title: Islamic Art Exhibition Postponed in Pittsburgh Amid Israel-Hamas War
description: The Frick Pittsburgh cited fears that the show could become “a source of unintended insensitivity or offense.”
content: The Frick Pittsburgh postponed an exhibition featuring 10 centuries of Islamic art that was supposed to open on Saturday, citing the outbreak of the Israel-Hamas war and the fear that the show could become “a source of unintended insensitivity or offense.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffery C. Mays
title: Asian Americans’ Political Strength and Alliances Face Test in New York
description: Whether they stick with Democrats or continue their shift to the right, Asian American voters will help decide competitive races on Nov. 7.
content: Two years ago, many Asian American voters in New York City demonstrated their political muscle by voting for Republicans in traditional Democratic enclaves, voicing their concerns about crime and education while sending a warning signal to Democrats.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: Who Killed the Innkeeper With a Sword in 1315?
description: A map pinpointing hundreds of homicides in 14th-century England could help teach medieval history.
content: A spice merchant stabbed by a fruit seller over a longstanding feud. A street musician murdered for playing music too loudly after dusk. A deadly quarrel among servants of the Queen of England. And who killed the innkeeper with a sword after a fight?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Flitter
title: Frustrated With New Rules, Bank Lobbyists Are Making Their Fight Public
description: Banking trade groups are using legal action and public campaigns to push back on rules they say go too far.
content: Banks have become increasingly frustrated with their federal regulators and, in a break with tradition, have brought the battle out into the open.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Jimmy Kimmel: Donald Trump Jr. Is ‘The Fraudigal Son’
description: Late night hosts poked fun at the former president’s eldest son after he testified on Wednesday in the civil fraud trial against the Trump family and their company.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lulu Garcia-Navarro, Ian Stewart, Allison Benedikt, Jessica Metzger and Dan Powell
title: A Surge in Antisemitism in Europe — and What’s Behind It
description: The latest from the Israel-Hamas war. Weekday afternoons with Lulu Garcia-Navarro and Times journalists on the ground.
content: This week, the director of the F.B.I. warned Congress that the Israel-Hamas war had escalated threats against Jews and Muslims in the United States, and that antisemitic threats had reached “historic levels.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Egan
title: Who Is Hannah Grace? And Why Won’t She Show Her Face?
description: The author of “Icebreaker” and “Wildfire” has her own reasons for avoiding the limelight.
content: Hannah Grace doesn’t have an author photo. She doesn’t do events. Neighbors in Manchester, England, don’t know that she’s written two best sellers, “Icebreaker” and “Wildfire,” nor do they know that the unassuming 30-year-old traded her corporate job to become a full-time novelist last year. That’s because Hannah Grace isn’t her real name; it’s a nom de plume.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives
title: Ady Barkan, Health Care Activist Spurred by His Illness, Dies at 39
description: Mr. Barkan campaigned for Medicare for all while struggling with A.L.S., the terminal neurodegenerative disease.
content: Ady Barkan, a well-known activist who campaigned for Medicare for all while struggling with the neurodegenerative disease A.L.S., died on Wednesday in Santa Barbara, Calif. He was 39.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green
title: ‘Pal Joey’ Review: Bewitched, Bothered and Bewildering
description: Joey is still a heel in this major revision of the 1940 antihero musical, but he’s now a Black artist trying to find his true voice.
content: It’s not often that the standout star of a show is its music supervisor, arranger or orchestrator, but in the gala presentation of “Pal Joey” at New York City Center through Sunday, all three are one man, Daryl Waters. More than the authors of the ambitious, bewildering revival’s new book, Waters, who has served similar roles on musicals as varied as “Bring in ’Da Noise, Bring in ’Da Funk,” “After Midnight,” “The Cher Show” and “New York, New York,” makes a clear case in beautiful sound for its investigation into the melting pot of American music.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Learning to Become Openhearted
description: Responses to a David Brooks column about how to connect with other people. Also: The kidnapping posters; older prisoners; human needs; extremists in control.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Britney Spears’s Memoir Sells 1.1 Million Copies in U.S. in First Week
description: Sales of “The Woman in Me,” which chronicles the pop star’s life, from stardom as a teen to the conservatorship that controlled much of her adulthood, demonstrate tremendous interest in Spears’s story.
content: Britney Spears’s much-anticipated memoir, “The Woman in Me,” sold 1.1 million copies in all formats in the United States in its first week on sale, the book’s publisher, Gallery Books, announced on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Astead W. Herndon, Caitlin O'Keefe and Grant Hindsley
title: The People of Clallam County Haven’t Gotten It Wrong Since 1980
description: Voters in the northernmost part of Washington State have picked the winner in every presidential election from Reagan to Biden. What do they think now?
content: Clallam County in Washington State is far from Washington, D.C. — almost as far as you can go without leaving the continental United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jordyn Holman
title: Holiday Retail Sales Are Expected to Increase, but at a Slower Pace
description: Spending in that crucial period is predicted to rise 3 to 4 percent from last year, as the economy cools and demand normalizes.
content: Holiday spending is expected to increase this year, but analysts foresee it slowing down from peak pandemic years, when Americans spent at record levels.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Fuller and Aaron Boxerman
title: Israeli Troops Encircle Gaza City as Global Criticism of Strikes Mounts
description: An Israeli military spokesman said that Israeli soldiers had surrounded Gaza’s largest city. White House officials said they would urge Israel to “pause” its bombardment on humanitarian grounds.
content: As the Israeli military announced that ground troops had encircled Gaza City on Thursday, criticism mounted of the death toll inflicted by Israeli airstrikes, with one United Nations agency suggesting the bombing campaign could be a war crime.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Guy Trebay
title: The Sudden Death of a Model Magnate
description: Over his three decades at the top of the industry, Ivan Bart helped engineer the careers of such top models as Gisele Bündchen, Kate Upton and Kate Moss.
content: Not without reason has modeling been termed the ugly business of being beautiful. Opaque, barely regulated and often cutthroat, it is seldom viewed as an incubator of big-hearted altruists. Yet when news came this week that Ivan Bart, the former president of IMG models, died suddenly at age 60 — following what was described as a brief illness — social media lit up with outpourings of praise for a man that Fern Mallis, a seasoned industry consultant and the author of “Fashion Lives: Fashion Icons with Fern Mallis,” called “one of the most delicious human beings you ever want to know.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sapna Maheshwari
title: TikTok Pushes Back Against Claims It Fuels Antisemitism
description: The company said it had removed millions of TikTok videos in recent weeks related to hate speech, hateful behavior, harassment and bullying.
content: TikTok pushed back on Thursday against growing claims in recent weeks that it had failed to protect Jewish users and had pushed pro-Palestinian content in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Do You Mind?
description: Chase Dittrich and Christina Iverson’s crossword messes with our brains, but that’s Thursday puzzles for you.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalia Winkelman
title: ‘Radical’ Review: To Sergio With Love
description: A vaguely unconventional teacher galvanizes disadvantaged sixth graders in this highly conventional drama.
content: Stop me if you’ve seen this one before: A free-spirited teacher takes a stake in a classroom full of underprivileged youth and unleashes their true potential. This stale and sometimes patronizing premise is recycled in Christopher Zalla’s “Radical,” a sentimental drama that is based on a true story but boxes neatly into familiar packaging. The title is nearly oxymoronic: It boldly belies how close to convention the film hews.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola and Ameera Harouda
title: Evacuating From Gaza Is Its Own Ordeal
description: For many, the path to the border crossing to reach Egypt has been filled with danger.
content: As people waited at the Rafah crossing on Thursday anticipating a second day of evacuations from Gaza into Egypt, the sound of an airstrike rattled the crowd, and a piece of shrapnel appeared to fall in the area.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee and Emma Bubola
title: ‘In Egypt Now. Free!’: First Evacuees From Gaza Feel Relief and Gratitude
description: “You feel that human beings’ lives are so worthless,” said Ala Al Husseini, 61, an Austrian-Palestinian dual national who was allowed to leave Gaza on Wednesday.
content: There was little gas and no phone service in Gaza on Wednesday morning, making it impossible to hail a cab, so Ala Al Husseini nearly missed his chance to escape the war.
source.name: The New York Times

title: In the Catskills, Seasonal Farmhouse Dinners With House-Made Beer
description: Plus: A boutique hotel in South Africa, a painter’s imaginary friends and more recommendations from T Magazine.
content: My morning routine is how I set myself up for the day. I splash my face with water and will often use Oskia’s Super C Beauty Capsules. I’m a big fan of Augustinus Bader’s The Light Cream and then Merit’s Great Skin Instant Glow Serum, which is very subtle. I’m really into their makeup: they have this Bronze Balm in a stick and blushers that come in little jars that are easy to swipe on. I use RMS UnCoverup Concealer and Supergoop Glowscreen SPF 40. I have an orangy red lipstick from NARS called Heatwave that I’ll wear here and there. I was on a shoot recently and the makeup artist told me about using this Schwarzkopf Styling Gel on your brows — it’s the only thing that actually stays for me. Kure nail varnish has the best range of colors and is the most durable of all the natural products; I like Rose Milk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Ito
title: Penn & Teller Don’t Mind Being Fooled
description: Now in its 10th season, “Penn & Teller: Fool Us” has become TV’s premier showcase for magicians and the rare competition show where kindness rules.
content: On the magician Shin Lim’s first appearance on “Penn & Teller: Fool Us,” he made cards rise out of a tabletop and vanish, only for them to reappear inside a clear sealed bag, or emerge from his mouth, engulfed in smoke and folded in four.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Sfard
title: Israel Is Silencing Internal Critics
description: Since the war between Israel and Hamas began, free speech in Israel has suffered.
content: On Oct. 25, Professor Nurit Peled-Elhanan, a lecturer at a college in Jerusalem, participated in a discussion in a faculty WhatsApp group about the horrific events of Oct. 7. In response to another lecturer’s message, she wrote that “the massacre,” referring to the actions of Hamas, reminded her of something the French philosopher and playwright Jean-Paul Sartre once wrote about race relations, adding a paraphrased quote: “‘After so many years that the neck of the occupied has been suffocating under your iron foot and suddenly was given a chance to raise his eyes, what kind of gaze did you expect you would see there?’ We saw this gaze,” Ms. Peled-Elhanan wrote to her colleagues.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Debra Kamin
title: Chief Executive of National Association of Realtors Resigns
description: The resignation of Bob Goldberg comes days after a $1.8 billion verdict against N.A.R. and two months after The New York Times exposed complaints of sexual harassment in the group.
content: The chief executive of the National Association of Realtors resigned from his post two days after a federal jury ruled that the powerful organization conspired to inflate home commissions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Kolomatsky
title: More American Seniors Live Alone
description: People over 60 are more likely to live alone in the United States and Europe than in other regions of the world.
content: Who will be by your side in your golden years? That’s a big question for a growing cohort. By 2050, the global population of people aged 60 and over will double from its 2020 total, to 2.1 billion, according to the World Health Organization. This week we examine the size of the households of this growing population in the United States compared with other regions of the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush
title: South Carolina Jails to Be Investigated After Reports of Abuse and Violence
description: The Justice Department inquiry will focus on “credible allegations” that a number of deaths at two jails resulted from use of force, medical neglect and assaults by inmates.
content: The Justice Department on Thursday opened a far-reaching civil rights investigation of two troubled jails in South Carolina after reports of violent and unhealthy living conditions, failure to treat mentally ill prisoners and the abuse of inmates by guards.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross
title: Microsoft Criticized for Embedding ‘Crass’ A.I. Poll Beside News Article
description: A poll generated by artificial intelligence, embedded next to a Guardian article on Microsoft’s news aggregator platform, asked readers to speculate on the cause of a woman’s death.
content: An auto-generated poll that Microsoft embedded on its news aggregating platform alongside a Guardian article was “crass” and caused The Guardian significant reputation damage, the newspaper said on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: THURSDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karoun Demirjian
title: Senators Plot to Unblock Military Promotions as Tuberville Draws G.O.P. Ire
description: Democrats were working to temporarily circumvent Senate rules to outmaneuver the Alabama Republican, and a group of senators in his own party signaled their patience had run out.
content: Senate Democrats are trying a novel strategy to break Senator Tommy Tuberville’s blockade of senior military promotions, as pressure builds among his fellow Republicans and Defense Department officials to end his monthslong hold in protest of the Pentagon’s abortion access policies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aric Toler
title: Dagestan Mob Riot Targeting Plane From Israel Was Weeks in the Making
description: A New York Times analysis of local Telegram channels showed posts falsely claiming Israeli refugees were incoming had been shared long before the antisemitic riot on Oct. 29.
content: A false rumor about the resettlement of Israelis in Dagestan that incited a violent mob at its capital airport Sunday was shared online for longer and more widely than previously reported, according to a New York Times analysis of Telegram posts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Caron
title: Don’t Shut Down Your Anger. Channel It.
description: We’re often told to focus on the positive. But new research shows a healthy dose of anger can be motivating.
content: There is an upside to feeling angry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Nereim
title: Saudi Arabia Begins Aid Effort for Gaza and Raises $17 Million in Hours
description: The belated campaign, announced more than three weeks into the war, appeared consistent with the Saudi government’s ambivalent response to the conflict.
content: Saudi Arabia on Thursday announced a government campaign to collect humanitarian aid for Gaza, gathering more than 60,000 donations worth more than $17 million in its first few hours.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeff Tweedy
title: Jeff Tweedy: I Thought I Hated Pop Music. ‘Dancing Queen’ Changed My Mind.
description: It feels good to come clean.
content: It’s important to admit when you’re wrong. And though I once bristled at the notion that there could ever be such a thing as a wrong musical opinion, I have since come to accept that there is, in fact, such a thing. I know because I had one: I was colossally wrong about the song “Dancing Queen” by Abba.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Small
title: Will the Art Market Need to Discount Its Masterpieces?
description: Amid fears that a new war could threaten the world economy, New York’s coming auctions will test a growing consensus that the $60 billion art market is headed toward a down cycle.
content: Major auction houses are hedging their bets in the fall season of sales that begins Monday, offering fat guarantees to sellers to secure their works — and pricing some of their top items more conservatively after the spring season demonstrated weakness in the blazing-hot $60 billion art market. And now, sellers are trying to anticipate how the uncertainty of a new war in the Middle East will affect them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Satariano
title: Elon Musk Discusses Perils and Benefits of A.I. With Rishi Sunak
description: The prime minister’s conversation with the tech billionaire was part of an effort this week to present Britain as a leader in artificial intelligence.
content: Rishi Sunak, the prime minister of Britain, had one last appointment on Thursday evening after a busy couple of days hosting dozens of government leaders, tech executives and other experts at a summit on the dangers of artificial intelligence: a sit-down with Elon Musk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Bradsher and Lisa Friedman
title: China Is Winning in Solar Power, but Its Coal Use Is Raising Alarms
description: China is building as much clean energy capacity over four years as it had promised to build in 10 years, but continues to add coal-fired power plants.
content: China is installing about as many solar panels and wind turbines as the rest of the world combined, and is on track to meet its target for clean energy six years early. It is using renewables to meet nearly all of the growth in its electricity needs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Kuo
title: Planned Museum to Honor Pulse Nightclub Victims Canceled
description: A foundation that had been working to create the museum said the cost of building it had become prohibitive. A permanent memorial is still planned for the site.
content: The nonprofit onePulse Foundation has ended its plans to construct a museum in Orlando to honor the victims of the Pulse nightclub shooting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Jewett
title: Vaping Declines Among High School Students, Survey Shows
description: The annual tobacco use survey given to middle and high school students revealed a decrease among older teenagers for the first time in several years.
content: The number of high school students who reported using e-cigarettes fell to 10 percent in the spring of this year from 14 percent last year, according to the results of an annual survey released on Thursday by federal health agencies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chevaz Clarke
title: A young woman describes the crisis in Gaza: ‘If the bombs didn’t kill us, our living situation will.’
description: Nour AlSaqqa, who is from Gaza City, has been documenting her life during the Israel-Hamas war. She said she fears that if the shortages of basic necessities persist, she will die.
content: Nour AlSaqqa, who is from Gaza City, has been documenting her life during the Israel-Hamas war. The New York Times last spoke to Ms. AlSaqqa when the war first started. Since then, she has fled south to Rafah, the Gazan city at the territory’s southern border with Egypt, after Israel warned Palestinians to leave northern Gaza to avoid airstrikes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick McGeehan
title: Wind Power, Key to Democrats’ Climate-Change Goals, Faces a Crisis
description: Instead of gathering momentum, the industry is confronting obstacles that could hinder its ability to realize the renewable resource’s promised benefits.
content: Before the end of this year, thousands of families in New York could be using electricity produced by a wind farm off the eastern tip of Long Island that will be the state’s first.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: Love Letters to California
description: Readers share why they adore living in the Golden State.
content: When it comes to waxing poetic about California, certain spots tend to get the most love. Among them: the palm-tree-lined beaches of Los Angeles, the Golden Gate Bridge, and the stunning waterfalls and granite mountains of Yosemite National Park.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nancy Hass
title: With ‘Lovers Grave,’ Tracey Emin Returns, at Full Emotional Volume
description: Her illness, her traumas and thorny romantic entanglements are writ loud in her art, on view at White Cube Nov. 4.
content: Tracey Emin carried around a giant tote decades before enormous handbags were fashionable. Back then, in the 1990s, when she was emerging as a gale-like force in a loosely affiliated group that came to be known as the Young British Artists, people often asked her — journalists, fans on London streets — What do you keep in there? She says the real answer was usually a sketch pad, her daily ration of three packs of Marlboro Lights, six Stella Artois beers and a fifth of brandy, but it was easier to say she needed a bag big enough to haul all her insecurities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeannette Catsoulis
title: ‘Fingernails’ Review: Love, Factually
description: Jessie Buckley and Riz Ahmed play confused lonely-hearts torn between science and emotion in this adorable near-future romance.
content: Heartache and horror walk hand in hand in “Fingernails,” a disarmingly sweet science-fiction romance from the Greek director Christos Nikou. Opening with a brief explanation of the title — the first sign of heart disease is often noticed in the fingernails — and closing on a note of indescribable yearning, this gently humorous movie operates so smoothly you may not notice its subversiveness.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Travelli and Hari Kumar
title: No Nation in the World Is Buying More Planes Than India. Here’s Why.
description: While most Indians travel by road or rail, the country is engaged in a major expansion of its aviation industry to serve the needs of its middle class.
content: No nation in the world is buying as many airplanes as India. Its largest airlines have ordered nearly 1,000 jets this year, committing tens of billions of dollars to a spending spree that is unparalleled in aviation. In New Delhi, Indira Gandhi International Airport will be ready for 109 million passengers next year, as it prepares to become the world’s second busiest, behind Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: U.S. to Press Israel for ‘Pauses’ in War With Hamas
description: Brief cessations of military operations would allow food, water and other aid to reach Gaza and help with hostage releases, officials say.
content: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken will urge the Israeli government to agree to a series of brief cessations of military operations in Gaza to allow for hostages to be released safely and for humanitarian aid to be distributed, White House officials said on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. Edward Moreno
title: Jury Begins Deliberations for a Verdict in Sam Bankman-Fried’s Trial
description: The trial for the founder of the collapsed FTX cryptocurrency exchange has moved more speedily than anticipated.
content: A jury of nine women and three men began deliberating a verdict on Thursday afternoon in the criminal fraud trial of Sam Bankman-Fried, the disgraced entrepreneur who has been accused of stealing as much as $10 billion in customer funds from his FTX crypto exchange.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Eligon
title: ‘More Than Just Rugby’: Championship Generates Harmony in South Africa
description: South Africans are savoring a second consecutive World Cup victory, producing a racial unity that even Hollywood couldn’t make up and an escape from the country’s troubles.
content: The towering hall thundered with the euphoria of a nation where everyone seemed, for the moment, to have left their differences behind.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Riley Mellen and Eric Schmitt
title: U.S. Drones Are Flying Over Gaza to Aid in Hostage Recovery, Officials Say
description: The military has been sending weapons and advisers to Israel, but the flights suggest a more active American role.
content: The U.S. military is flying surveillance drones over the Gaza Strip, according to two Defense Department officials and an analysis by The New York Times. The officials said the drones were being used to aid in hostage recovery efforts, indicating that the U.S. is more involved than previously known.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pashtana Usufzy and Julia Jacobs
title: Man Accused in Tupac Shakur’s Murder Pleads Not Guilty
description: The suspect, Duane Keith Davis, faces a charge of murder with a deadly weapon. He has spoken openly about his presence at the scene in a memoir and interviews.
content: A man who for years has said he was a critical player in the gang-orchestrated shooting of the rapper Tupac Shakur pleaded not guilty on Thursday to a charge of murder with a deadly weapon, following an indictment that thrust the dormant case back into public view.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pamela Paul
title: The Democrats Are Their Own Worst Enemies
description: John B. Judis and Ruy Teixeira say the Democratic Party is failing in matters of culture and in matters of class.
content: This should be the Democratic Party’s moment. Donald Trump’s stranglehold has lurched the G.O.P. toward the fringe. Republican congressional behavior echoes that of an intemperate toddler and the party’s intellectual and ideological foundations have become completely unmoored.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Brooks
title: How to Stay Sane in Brutalizing Times
description: Ancient wisdom can help keep us from becoming calloused over.
content: We’re living in a brutalizing time: Scenes of mass savagery pervade the media. Americans have become vicious toward one another amid our disagreements. Everywhere I go, people are coping with an avalanche of negative emotions: shock, pain, contempt, anger, anxiety, fear.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Goldstein
title: Ken Mattingly, Astronaut Scrubbed From Apollo 13, Is Dead at 87
description: He later orbited the moon, but in 1970 he was bumped from the Apollo flight after being exposed to measles. Then, from mission control, he helped it avert disaster.
content: Ken Mattingly, who orbited the moon and commanded a pair of NASA shuttle missions, but who was remembered as well for the flight he didn’t make — the near-disastrous mission of Apollo 13 — died on Tuesday in Arlington, Va. He was 87.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Celebrity Relationships, Police Robots and the Mall: Argumentative Writing by Teens
description: Teenagers weigh in on the news of the day in three recent Picture Prompts.
content: Taylor Swift and Travis Kelce. A 400-pound “fully autonomous” security robot in New York City’s subway stations. The value of shopping malls.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut and Andrew E. Kramer
title: Ukraine’s Top Commander Says War Has Hit a ‘Stalemate’
description: In a candid assessment, Gen. Valery Zaluzhny said no “beautiful breakthrough” was imminent and that breaking the deadlock could require advances in technological warfare.
content: Ukraine’s top commander has acknowledged that his forces are locked in a “stalemate” with Russia along a front line that has barely shifted despite months of fierce fighting, and that no significant breakthrough was imminent. It is the most candid assessment so far by a leading Ukrainian official of the military’s stalled counteroffensive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: Woman Charged With Murder in Suspected Mushroom Poisoning Case
description: In a case that has gripped Australia, three people fell ill and died soon after eating lunch at the home of a relative.
content: Three of the four guests who attended a family lunch in a quiet Australian country town died shortly afterward, with symptoms the police said were consistent with mushroom poisoning. The fourth spent nearly two months hospitalized, critically ill.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chantel Tattoli
title: Her Clothes? Fabulous. Her Face? A Fungus.
description: Ewa Juszkiewicz’s paintings depict well-dressed women whose faces are hidden by mushrooms, textiles and wild hairdos.
content: Ewa Juszkiewicz was staring at a portrait of Katarzyna Starzenska, a Polish aristocrat and social fixture, completed in 1804.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Santul Nerkar
title: Six Flags Merges With Cedar Fair, a Rival Amusement Park
description: The deal would generate more than $3 billion in revenue for the companies, they projected in a statement. The merger comes after years of financial challenges for Six Flags.
content: Six Flags, an amusement park corporation, is merging with its rival Cedar Fair in an $8 billion deal, the two companies announced on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katrina Miller
title: NASA’s Lucy Mission Set Its Sights on 1 Asteroid. It Found 2.
description: On its way to the Trojan swarms, the spacecraft made a pit stop at a rock named Dinkinesh — and the images it sent back revealed that this asteroid has its own moon.
content: On Wednesday, NASA’s Lucy spacecraft zoomed by its first asteroid target — and scientists on the mission were shocked to discover that the rock, named Dinkinesh, was actually two rocks. The binary consists of a larger, primary asteroid and a smaller “moon” orbiting around it, as seen in images that Lucy captured of the pair.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Whet Moser
title: Friday Briefing: China pushes for women to stay home
description: Plus New Zealand curlers take over a retirement home
content: The National Women’s Congress, held every five years, has long been a forum for the ruling Communist Party to demonstrate its commitment to women. This year, officials downplayed gender equality and focused on President Xi Jinping’s goal for Chinese women: Get married and have babies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffrey Gettleman, Rami Nazzal and Adam Sella
title: How a Campaign of Extremist Violence Is Pushing the West Bank to the Brink
description: Israeli settlers and Palestinians have been locked in a cycle of bloodshed for decades. But extremist settler attacks could send the conflict out of control.
content: This past Saturday morning, Bilal Mohammad Saleh, a Palestinian sidewalk vendor of sage and thyme, went out with his family to pick olives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: House Passes Aid Bill for Israel but Not for Ukraine
description: The Republican-led House approved $14.3 billion for Israel’s war with Hamas, tying the aid to spending cuts. The Senate plans to craft its own bill that will include aid for Ukraine and Gaza.
content: A divided House on Thursday passed a Republican-written bill that would tie $14.3 billion in military aid for Israel to domestic spending cuts and provide no money for Ukraine, defying President Biden and dooming its chances in the Senate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Concepción de León
title: ‘Going to Mars: The Nikki Giovanni Project’ Review: An Afrofuturist Space Odyssey
description: The experimental documentary is punctuated by Giovanni’s poetry, read both by her and the actress Taraji P. Henson. But the film offers only what the poet is willing to give.
content: Nikki Giovanni wants to die in zero gravity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: What Question Would You Ask a Politician?
description: A 15-year-old has been asking presidential candidates tough questions on the campaign trial. What questions would you pose to someone in a position of power?
content: Have you ever wanted to ask a politician, or someone in a position of power, a tough question but were too afraid to ask?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bob Mehr
title: Kirsty MacColl’s Voice Was Singular. A New Box Aims to Bring It Wider.
description: The singer-songwriter, who died in 2000, is best known for duetting on “Fairytale of New York.” But in an unusual career, she also made her mark behind the scenes.
content: During a fitful 20-year solo career, the singer-songwriter Kirsty MacColl released just five full-length albums, achieving a modicum of success in her native England, and little notice in America. Yet MacColl — who died at 41 in 2000 — is omnipresent each holiday season: It’s her voice offering tart rejoinders to Shane MacGowan in the Pogues’ cockeyed Christmas anthem “Fairytale of New York.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Ley and Kellen Browning
title: Uber and Lyft Agree to $328 Million Payout for New York Drivers
description: The ride-share companies will also give gig workers sick leave and minimum pay.
content: Uber and Lyft have agreed to pay New York drivers a $328 million settlement after the state attorney general investigated a wage-theft complaint charging that the companies collected certain taxes and fees from drivers rather than passengers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil MacFarquhar
title: Russia Pulled Out of a Nuclear Test Ban Treaty. Here’s What That Means.
description: In de-ratifying the agreement, Moscow removed another brick in the wall of formal arms control intended to limit proliferation.
content: In a landmark moment marking the closing chapters of the Cold War, Presidents Ronald Reagan of the United States and Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union concluded a 1985 summit in Geneva by issuing a joint statement declaring that “a nuclear war cannot be won and must never be fought.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tanya Sichynsky
title: The Sun Is Setting Early. Time for Mushrooms.
description: Savory, hearty recipes that feel especially cozy as the days get shorter.
content: I tend to commute home on autopilot, taking in very little around me as I zone out to music so loud that my Health app insists I turn it down. So when I emerged from the subway the other day just before 6 p.m., I was startled by what I found: near complete darkness.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Naveen Kumar
title: ‘Poor Yella Rednecks’ Review: A Writer’s Origin Story Remixes Conventions
description: Qui Nguyen’s crowd-tickling comedy about a Vietnamese family in Arkansas mixes hip-hop and martial arts with soapy twists and turns.
content: The playwright Qui Nguyen has made a career of imagining marginalized people as heroic leads. That includes his parents, who emigrated from Vietnam and met in an Arkansas refugee camp, a story Nguyen chronicled in his raunchy rom-com-style play “Vietgone.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Israel, the I.R.S. and the Big Grift
description: Holding national security hostage to help tax cheats.
content: Historians of propaganda are familiar with the concept of the Big Lie, a claim so extreme that many people end up accepting it because they can’t believe that authority figures would make up something so at odds with reality.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman and Alan Feuer
title: Two Judges, Two Approaches
description: He avoids criticizing one. Another draws attacks.
content: As the two federal criminal cases against Donald Trump make their way toward trial, they are bringing into focus a tale of two judges.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Familiar Fear Gripping Jews Across Europe
description: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, November 2, 2023.
content: “France is seeing a wave of antisemitism not equaled since 1945.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Film Club: ‘Pick a Side. Pick a Side. Pick a Side. Now.’
description: In the Israel-Hamas War, social media demands that we have to choose a side. A Times Opinion video wonders whether we really do.
content: “Pick a Side. Pick a Side. Pick a Side. Now.” is a four-minute Opinion video that explores the role of social media in the current Israel-Hamas war, and whether it allows any space for nuance or neutrality. “The insistence on picking a side,” the Times filmmakers argue, “threatens the public’s ability to take a holistic view of what is happening, to recognize and acknowledge atrocities irrespective of their perpetrators and to honor and mourn those who lost their lives.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Taub
title: The Laws of War Have Limits. What Does That Mean for the Hamas-Israel War?
description: For many readers, the events of the past few weeks have raised profound and vexing questions that can illustrate the limits and strengths of international law.
content: It has been 26 days since Hamas launched its attacks on Israel. In my column a few days after the conflict began, I said that international law offered a framework for analyzing what was happening, even while the atrocities committed by Hamas were still being documented, and as the consequences of Israel’s devastating airstrikes on Gaza and cutoff of food, water and fuel were beginning to unfold.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Hale
title: ‘All the Light We Cannot See’ Review: The Blind Girl and the Nazi
description: A Netflix mini-series brings to the screen Anthony Doerr’s Pulitzer-winning World War II romance.
content: Marie-Laure and Werner, the destined soul mates who will eventually meet in the Netflix mini-series “All the Light We Cannot See,” are on opposite sides of a cataclysmic divide. She is a French teenager delivering coded radio messages to the Allied bombing command in World War II; he is a young Nazi radio technician assigned to track her down in her Saint-Malo garret, as the bombs rain and American troops close in.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Flavelle
title: Rich Nations Cut Aid for Climate Shocks, Even as Risks Grew
description: Poor countries need far more money to adapt to climate change, according to a new United Nations report.
content: Wealthy countries have decreased the amount of money they commit for helping developing countries cope with the effects of climate change, even as the need for that spending has grown, the United Nations said in a report issued on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Lewiston Begins to Heal, One Touchdown at a Time
description: At the season’s last football game, between rival high schools in Lewiston and Auburn, two broken cities in Maine found joy again.
content: The Battle of the Bridge is the biggest football game of the year in Lewiston and Auburn, cities separated by a river in Maine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Holly Williams
title: ‘Treason,’ the Musical Where the Fans Came First
description: The producers cultivated online followers for three years before mounting a full production, bringing them along on the show’s journey to the stage.
content: The catchy, folk-tinged numbers from “Treason the Musical” have been streamed online over a million times, in 96 countries. Its fans — known as “Plotters” — have been listening to an EP, an acoustic record and a live album of the songs, as well as sharing their own performances on TikTok. But until this fall, there hadn’t even been a full-scale production of the show.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia and Andrew Testa
title: In Shetland, the Hottest Event of the Year Stars Sheep and Knitters
description: The festival of the intricately crafted textiles of the Shetland Islands, a remote archipelago off Scotland’s coast, draws hundreds of knitters from around the world for all things wool.
content: The sheep came spilling over the hillside, emerging through the low mist where the green earth touched the gray sky, running down into the fields below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Bruni
title: Mike Pence’s Hell Is Ours Too
description: Brace yourselves for an apocalyptic campaign season.
content: It’s one thing to disparage Donald Trump. It’s quite another to throw your body between him and his efforts to steal the presidency. Mike Pence, God love him, did the latter, and that sealed his doom. To the hard-core MAGA corps, tyranny is the meaty breakfast of champions. Virtue and democracy are a wimp’s veggie canapés.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Jeff Tweedy Used to Browse Encyclopedias for Hours on End
description: “I read them the way that people surf the internet today, maybe,” says the Wilco frontman, whose new memoir is “World Within a Song.” “So I know everything.”
content: What books are on your night stand?
source.name: The New York Times

title: Trump’s Sons Cast the Blame for Fraud on Their Company’s Accountants
description: Donald Trump Jr. and his brother Eric Trump both testified in the  trial that accuses their family business of overvaluing its assets.
content: Eric and Donald J. Trump Jr., the elder sons of the 45th president, stepped out of their father’s shadow and into a legal minefield on Thursday, tiptoeing around potentially damaging evidence as they testified in a trial that threatens their family business.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Salam
title: Second Woman Accuses Steven Tyler of Sexually Assaulting Her in the 1970s
description: In a lawsuit, a woman says that the Aerosmith frontman groped and fondled her in a New York phone booth when she was about 17.
content: For the second time in the past year, Steven Tyler has been accused in a lawsuit of sexually assaulting a teenage girl in the 1970s, when his band Aerosmith was rising to fame.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times Cooking
title: ‘This is the Best Caesar Dressing I’ve Tasted. Ever.’
description: Readers love, really love, our vegan Caesar salad.
content: It’s that time of year when, inevitably, you will be asked to bring a salad to a gathering. You could hardly do better than this reader-favorite vegan Caesar salad with crispy chickpeas, a brilliant recipe by Becky Hughes. (For anyone who thinks it’s not a real Caesar without the egg yolks and anchovies, don’t worry, we have a salad for you, too.) Becky’s creamy dressing is built on a base of blended raw cashews, punched up with plenty of garlic, miso and caper brine. It’s bound to win fans, vegan or not: “Forget best vegan Caesar dressing — this is the best Caesar dressing I’ve tasted. Ever,” wrote Sarah, a reader.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Rosman
title: An ‘Israel Explainer’ Makes Her Country’s Case in America
description: Once a celebrated actress in Israel, Noa Tishby has emerged as a leading pro-Israel voice on U.S. TV, on social media and in print.
content: On a stage in Los Angeles last week, two Israeli-born women sat before a rapt audience, discussing their grief and anger in the wake of the Oct. 7 attack on Israel by Hamas terrorists. More than 500 people had crowded into a synagogue auditorium to listen, and 400 more tuned in via Zoom.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas L. Friedman
title: The Two Things Worrying U.S. Military Officials About Israel and Hamas
description: Israel, Iran, Ukraine and Russia are driving so much about geopolitics today.
content: Step back far enough, and you can see exactly what is driving so much geopolitics today: Ukraine is trying to join the West. Israel is trying to join a new Middle East. And Russia and Iran have teamed up to try to block both.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hamilton Cain
title: Welcome to Ed Park’s Many-Layered World
description: “Same Bed Different Dreams” is the rare sophomore novel that has the wild, freewheeling ambition of a debut.
content: Just after I’d registered for my first semester of college courses, I was meandering among a concourse of clubs and teams, fending off their grinning ambassadors, when a newspaper headline caught my eye: “U.S. Says Soviet Downed Korean Airliner; 269 Lost.” By today’s standards the KAL 007 tragedy seems like a distant relic of Ronald Reagan’s “evil empire” rhetoric, but at the time it was a Cold War grenade: Jet fighters scrambled, sabers rattled, tinfoil-hat theories spiked. Late in his lush, labyrinthine “Same Bed Different Dreams,” Ed Park recreates that moment, twisting the doomed flight’s number into a James Bond motif that resonates throughout the novel. Double agents, sinister corporations, slasher films, U.F.O.s: If Park’s suitcase is stuffed, well, it’s an inspired choice for an odyssey that unpacks, in Pynchonesque fashion, Korean history and American paranoia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: ‘Beyond Utopia’ Review: Exit Strategies
description: This film, directed by Madeleine Gavin, documents the experiences of defectors from North Korea.
content: “Beyond Utopia,” a documentary on defectors from North Korea, begins by pre-empting the inevitable questions about how it was made. “The film contains no recreations,” the opening titles explain. The footage, we are told, was shot by the filmmakers, the subjects and operatives in the underground network that helped those subjects escape.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Goldberg and Sapna Maheshwari
title: On Social Media, People Face Pressure to Speak Out About the War
description: Silence is viewed by many as its own statement. Posting, though, can come with costs, including angry outpourings and even personal attacks.
content: Deb Perelman, the best-selling cookbook author and creator of Smitten Kitchen, tends to focus her social media posts on her work, like pasta or chocolate chip cookie recipes. But days after Hamas attacked Israel, she called the violence “repugnant” on Instagram and expressed dread for “death and destruction now ahead on both sides.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Today, Shapewear. Tomorrow, the World.
description: Kim Kardashian’s Skims hooks up with Swarovski to bedazzle the body.
content: One Friday afternoon, not long after unleashing the “Skims ultimate nipple bra” on the internet — a bra with a built-in erect nipple — and just before announcing that Skims was going to be the official underwear partner of the N.B.A., W.N.B.A. and USA Basketball, Kim Kardashian was sitting in her office in Calabasas, Calif., framed by two picture windows that offered views of manicured green lawns, and talking about size. Specifically, how big she wanted Skims to be.

author: By Cassandra Vinograd
title: Deadly Storm Ciarán Lashes U.K. and Western Europe With Strong Rain and Wind
description: With winds expected to exceed 85 miles per hour in some areas, Britain’s weather agency issued its second-highest level of alert for parts of southern England.
content: A storm that battered northwestern France overnight lashed Britain and much of Western Europe on Thursday with heavy rains and strong winds that left at least six people dead.

author: By Eshe Nelson
title: Bank of England Holds Rates Steady Amid Signs of Weakening Economy
description: Britain’s central bank said that interest rates would need to remain high for an “extended” period, and that economic growth was expected to be flat over much of the next two years.
content: The Bank of England held interest rates at the highest levels in 15 years on Thursday, though policymakers were again divided on the best course of action to stamp out high inflation.

title: Poem: […]
description: In this poem from a Palestinian American writer, absence becomes atmosphere.
content: Fady Joudah’s poem, written in the past few weeks, begins with its title’s conspicuous absence. The square brackets that conventionally indicate the first line of an untitled poem here surround an ellipsis, the typographical mark of omission. The weight of the unsaid and the unspeakable, the lost and the left out, hangs over the poem’s head. Perhaps it is Palestine. What is missing defies proportion. It could be as vast as history, as small as a child’s breath. Absence becomes atmosphere. America becomes object: a proverbial impossibility, both the flood and the ark. Selected by Anne Boyer
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John McWhorter
title: The Trap of the Overprotected Childhood
description: I wish my kids had the open-ended, play-filled days I had growing up.
content: Not long ago, I visited the quiet, treesy neighborhood I spent much of my 1970s childhood in. It was late afternoon on a weekday. Fifty years ago, there would have been lots of kids roaming and biking around in the streets; I was one of them. But on the day I was there, there was not a single child to be seen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeré Longman
title: Kenyan Runners Set the World’s Pace, Chased by a Doping Crisis
description: Nearly 300 athletes from Kenya have been punished for using banned substances since 2015, tarnishing the country’s image as a running powerhouse.
content: When Kelvin Kiptum, of Kenya, broke the world marathon record in early October, he threatened a landmark barrier of human possibility: running 26.2 miles in less than two hours in a competitive race.

author: By Amy Nicholson
title: ‘Nyad’ Review: Neptune’s (Estranged) Daughter
description: Annette Bening plays the long-distance swimmer Diana Nyad as a woman who doesn’t pity herself. Neither does the film.
content: “Nyad” is about an athlete creating her own lore. Diana Nyad (Annette Bening) is proud that her last name stems from the naiads of Greek mythology. “My ancestors! The nymphs that swam in the lakes and the rivers and the ocean,” Diana trumpets to everyone in earshot. A record-breaking long-distance swimmer, she’s got the lung capacity of a real blowhard. Her ever-patient best friend, Bonnie (Jodie Foster), spends this exuberant and enervating biopic cutting Diana off mid-crow. Braggadocio takes you far in politics or business; jocks, however, have to prove it in sweat. And so, at 60, Diana vows to conquer the challenge that bested her at age 28. She’ll swim nonstop from Cuba to Florida — over two days of sharks, storms, stinging jellyfish and hallucinatory exhaustion. For most of this riveting crowd-pleaser, she fails.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David French
title: The Laws of Campus Culture War
description: College can be contentious, but it must be safe and free.
content: These are times that try our commitment to the Bill of Rights. Grief, rage and fear are radiating outward from the Middle East and tearing at the fabric of our own liberal democracy, especially on college campuses. The stories are already legion. Activists have ripped down posters of kidnapped Israeli women and children. The chancellor of the State University System of Florida ordered the deactivation of two campus chapters of Students for Justice in Palestine. At Cooper Union in New York City, Jewish students sheltered inside the library while pro-Palestinian protesters pounded on the doors. And in Ithaca, N.Y., a Cornell University student was arrested after publishing vile threats against the school’s Jewish community.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brandon Yu
title: ‘Quiz Lady’ Review: Dog in Jeopardy
description: Sandra Oh shines in this road trip buddy comedy about a pair of sisters getting on a TV quiz show to pay the ransom for their stolen dog.
content: Jenny (Sandra Oh), a 40-something ball of chaos, is introduced in “Quiz Lady” the way you might expect of someone whose life savings are contingent on a hazardous fish bone-related lawsuit against a chain restaurant called Choochie’s: off in the distance, skittering heedlessly across the street before she’s suddenly struck by a car. Naturally, she pops right back up before having a meltdown over the mechanical entrance to the senior home where her younger sister, Anne (Awkwafina), is frustratingly watching from inside.

title: ‘The Marsh King’s Daughter’ Review: Smoke on the Water

content: In the director Neil Burger’s harrowing yet thin thriller “The Marsh King’s Daughter,” adapted from Karen Dionne’s same-titled novel, a young Helena (Brooklynn Prince) learns how her fairy tale is actually a nightmare. She lives in a woodland cabin with her stern mother, Beth (Caren Pistorius) and her huntsman father, Jacob (Ben Mendelsohn). Jacob often brands Beth’s white skin with Indigenous inspired tattoos and instructs her how to track and hunt.
